DEVICE STRUCTURE:
***Device***
Name: Kitchen Ceiling Fan
  ***Properties***
    Speed
      Range 0 to 5 Unit level
        Off [0]
    Direction
      Enum
        Forward [0]
        Reverse [1]
    Timer
      Range 0 to 120 Unit minutes
  ***Accept Commands***
    Set Speed [SSPD]
      Parameter 1: []
        Range 0 to 5 Unit level
    Set Direction [SDIR]
      Parameter 1: []
        Enum
          Forward [0]
          Reverse [1]
    Set Timer [STMR]
      Parameter 1: []
        Range 0 to 120 Unit minutes
    Turn Off [TOFF]
    Turn On [TON]
  ***Send Commands***
    Report Speed [RSPD]
    Report Direction [RDIR]
    Report Timer [RTMR]

USER QUERY:
Can you set the kitchen fan to speed level 3 and make it spin in reverse direction for 45 minutes?

To fulfill this request, I first identify the relevant properties and commands. The fan speed property ranges from 0 (off) to 5, and the user wants speed level 3, which is valid. The direction property is an enum with Forward [0] and Reverse [1]; the user wants Reverse. The timer property accepts values from 0 to 120 minutes; 45 minutes is within range.

The accepted commands to achieve this are Set Speed (SSPD) with parameter 3, Set Direction (SDIR) with parameter Reverse [1], and Set Timer (STMR) with parameter 45.

Therefore, the assistant should send these commands in sequence: set speed to 3, set direction to reverse, and set timer to 45 minutes.

Result: Execute SSPD(3), SDIR(1), and STMR(45) to set the kitchen ceiling fan to speed 3, reverse direction, for 45 minutes.
You are a smart home assistant and NuCore expert.

      Enum
        Low [0]

        High [2]
  ***Accept Commands***

      Parameter 1: []

      Parameter 1: []
        Enum
          Off [0]
          Heat [1]
          Cool [2]
          Auto [3]

    Turn On [TON]
  ***Send Commands***

    Report Mode [RM]

USER QUERY:
I want to set the thermostat to cool mode at 22.5 degrees Celsius with the fan on high speed.

The user wants to set three parameters: mode, target temperature, and fan speed. The device supports these via Set Mode (SM), Set Target Temperature (STT), and Set Fan Speed (SFS) commands.

First, the mode 'Cool' corresponds to enum value 2, which is valid. The target temperature 22.5 °C is within the allowed range 10.0 to 30.0 °C. The fan speed 'High' corresponds to enum value 2.

Therefore, the assistant should send the commands: SM(2) to set mode to cool, STT(22.5) to set target temperature, and SFS(2) to set fan speed to high.

Result: Execute Set Mode with parameter 2 (Cool), Set Target Temperature with 22.5 °C, and Set Fan Speed with 2 (High).
You are a smart home assistant and NuCore expert.

***Device***
Name: Garage Door Controller
  ***Properties***
    Status
      Enum
        Closed [0]
        Open [1]
        Opening [2]
        Closing [3]
    Lock
      Enum
        Locked [0]
        Unlocked [1]
  ***Accept Commands***
    Open Door [OPD]
    Close Door [CLD]
    Lock Door [LKD]
    Unlock Door [UKD]
    Query Status [QST]
  ***Send Commands***
    Report Status [RST]
    Report Lock State [RLS]

USER QUERY:
Is the garage door currently locked and closed?

To answer this, I need to check the properties 'Status' and 'Lock'. The 'Status' property can be Closed [0], Open [1], Opening [2], or Closing [3]. The 'Lock' property can be Locked [0] or Unlocked [1].

The assistant can send Report Status (RST) and Report Lock State (RLS) commands to retrieve current states.

If the status reports Closed [0] and lock reports Locked [0], then the door is locked and closed.

Result: Query the device with RST and RLS commands. If responses are Closed and Locked, then yes, the garage door is currently locked and closed.
You are a smart home assistant and NuCore expert.

***Device***
Name: Bedroom Window Shade
  ***Properties***
    Position
      Range 0 to 100 Unit %
        Fully Closed [0]
        Fully Open [100]
    Tilt Angle
      Range -90 to 90 Unit degrees
  ***Accept Commands***
    Set Position [SPOS]
      Parameter 1: []
        Range 0 to 100 Unit %
    Set Tilt [STLT]
      Parameter 1: []
        Range -90 to 90 Unit degrees
    Open Shade [OPSH]
    Close Shade [CLSH]
    Stop Movement [STPM]
  ***Send Commands***
    Report Position [RPOS]
    Report Tilt [RTLT]

USER QUERY:
Please open the bedroom shade halfway and tilt it to 30 degrees upward.

The user wants to set the shade position to 50% (halfway open) and tilt angle to 30 degrees upward. The position property ranges from 0 to 100%, and 50% is valid. The tilt angle ranges from -90 to 90 degrees; 30 degrees is within range.

The accepted commands to achieve this are Set Position (SPOS) with parameter 50 and Set Tilt (STLT) with parameter 30.

Therefore, the assistant should send SPOS(50) to open the shade halfway and STLT(30) to tilt it upward by 30 degrees.

Result: Execute Set Position with 50% and Set Tilt with 30 degrees to open the bedroom shade halfway and tilt it upward.

***Device***
Name: Outdoor Sprinkler System
  ***Properties***
    Zone
      Range 1 to 8 Unit number
    Duration
      Range 1 to 60 Unit minutes
    Status
      Enum
        Off [0]
        On [1]
  ***Accept Commands***
    Start Zone [STZ]
      Parameter 1: []
        Range 1 to 8 Unit number
    Stop Zone [SPZ]
      Parameter 1: []
        Range 1 to 8 Unit number
    Set Duration [SDUR]
      Parameter 1: []
        Range 1 to 60 Unit minutes
    Turn Off All [TOFF]
  ***Send Commands***
    Report Status [RSTS]

USER QUERY:
Can you start zone 4 for 20 minutes on the sprinkler system?

The user wants to start watering zone 4 for 20 minutes. The zone property accepts values from 1 to 8, and 4 is valid. The duration property accepts 1 to 60 minutes, and 20 is valid.

The accepted commands are Start Zone (STZ) with parameter zone number and Set Duration (SDUR) with parameter duration.

To fulfill the request, first set the duration to 20 minutes using SDUR(20), then start zone 4 using STZ(4).

Result: Execute Set Duration with 20 minutes, then Start Zone with 4 to water zone 4 for 20 minutes.

USER QUERY:
Please lower the refrigerator temperature to 4 degrees Celsius and turn on the ice maker.

The user wants to set the refrigerator temperature to 4 °C and turn on the ice maker. The temperature property ranges from 1 to 10 °C, so 4 °C is valid.

The accepted commands are Set Temperature (STMP) with parameter 4 and Turn Ice Maker On (TIMO).

Therefore, the assistant should send STMP(4) to lower the temperature and TIMO to turn on the ice maker.

Result: Execute Set Temperature with 4 °C and Turn Ice Maker On command to fulfill the request.

USER QUERY:
Could you set the laundry room light to 75% brightness with a ramp rate of 1.0 minute and enable responding?

The user wants to set the laundry room light brightness to 75%, set the ramp rate to 1.0 minute, and enable responding.

From the device structure, the 'On Level' property ranges from 0 to 100%, so 75% is valid. The 'Ramp Rate' property is an enum with 1.0 minute corresponding to value 12. The 'Responding' property is an enum with True [0] and False [1]; enabling responding means setting it to True [0].

The accepted commands to set these are On Level (OL) with parameter 75, Ramp Rate (RR) with parameter 12, and presumably a command to set Responding, but Responding is a property only; no direct command is listed to set it. Since no command is listed to set Responding, it may be read-only or set via Write Changes (WDU) after property changes.

Therefore, the assistant should send OL(75) to set brightness, RR(12) to set ramp rate, and then WDU to write changes, which may include enabling responding.

Result: Execute On Level with 75%, Ramp Rate with 1.0 minute (12), and Write Changes to enable responding on the laundry room light.

USER QUERY:
I want to quickly turn on the laundry room light to full brightness and set the backlight to 40%.

The user wants to quickly turn on the laundry room light at full brightness (100%) and set the backlight to 40%.

From the device structure, the 'On' command with parameter 100% will turn on the light at full brightness. The 'Fast On' command (DFON) is available to quickly turn on the light, but it does not take a parameter; it likely turns on at the last or default level.

To ensure full brightness quickly, the best approach is to send the Fast On command (DFON) and then set the On Level (OL) to 100% to guarantee brightness. Alternatively, sending On (DON) with 100% parameter will turn on at full brightness but may not be as fast as Fast On.

The backlight property accepts values from 0 to 100%. The Backlight (BL) command accepts a parameter from 0 to 100%.

Therefore, the assistant should send DFON to fast on the light, then BL(40) to set backlight to 40%.

Result: Execute Fast On command to quickly turn on the light, then Backlight with 40% to set the backlight level.
